intro: Linum anglicum, commonly known as Common Flax, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It features slender, erect stems that can grow up to 1 meter in height, often branching near the top. The plant produces small, blue or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and covered in fine hairs. Linum anglicum is cultivated for its fibers, which are used in the production of linen, and it also has historical uses in herbal medicine.
